He makes his sales in the regional markets of his community, from which he obtains his weekly income, which has contributed to improving the quality of life of his family. He is applying for a loan of 7500 quetzales for working capital to buy and sell maxan leaves and to be able to increase his sales. His short term goal is to be able to see his products in other regional markets and to increase his sales with the goal of improving the well-being of his family.

loans.use: to buy maxan leaves to sell

loans.name: Kosau

texts.en: Kosau remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Kosau, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Kosau  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 50 bags per hectare this season. “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community” expressed Kosau. With this loan, Kosau is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase second-hand clothing.

loans.name: Saudah

texts.en: Saudah is married with three children, two of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (her mother). She has a business of selling fresh food and has been in this business for 10 years. She has applied for a loan of 400,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bags of sweet potatoes, cassava and bags of finger bananas. She generates additional income from rearing chickens.  She works at the market seven days out of every week and sells both retail and wholesale.  Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves.  She aspires to sell wholesale only and to buy a plot of land and build her own house. She decided to join MCDT-SACCO because she wanted additional capital for her business.  She resides in rented house and the family has no access to electricity, but has access to piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees

loans.use: To buy more  bags of sweet potatoes, cassava and bags of finger banana.

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
La señora María Elena  de  66  años de edad, no  tiene hijos que dependen de ella, es madre soltera  y vive en casa de un hermano, en una comunidad de  San Lorenzo, valle al sur de Honduras y se dedica desde hace 06 años a la actividad de venta de tamales pisques, tamal de gallina, pastelitos, etc. 
Doña María Elena  sus clientes son los amigos, vecinos y personas que viven en zonas aledañas a su comunidad, se transporta en un carretón a vender dichos productos, antes lo hacía a pie y ya está cansada por eso decidió comprarse este medio de transporte que le ha beneficiado mucho ya que ahora visita mas lugares y por ende vende más. 
Doña María Elena  está solicitando el préstamo para compra de alambres, tubos, pegamentos, mano de obra,  material para instalar la luz y el agua en su casa, también invertirá en materia prima como hojas de tamales, gallina y frijoles para elaborar sus tamalitos.
Doña María Elena  con el  apoyo del crédito pretende mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Junio del 2014.
texts.en:
Maria Elena is 66 years of age. She is a single mother but has no children who still depend on her. She lives in her brother's house, in the community of San Lorenzo, in a valley in the south of Honduras. 

For that past 6 years, Maria Elena has been working in the sale of tamales pisques, chicken tamales, pastries, etc. Maria Elena's clients include her friends, neighbors and people who live in nearby towns. She uses a small cart to sell her products. She used to sell on foot but this was tiring so she decided to buy this type of transportation which has benefited her greatly as she can now visit more places and thus, sell more.

Maria Elena is requesting this loan to buy tie wires, tubes, glue, labor, materials to set up electricity and water usage in her house. She will also use the loan to buy raw materials such as tamal leaves, chicken and beans to prepare her tamales. Maria Elena hopes to improve her qualify of life and that of her family with the help of this loan.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - June 2014.

loans.use: to buy tie wires, tubes, glue, labor, tamales, chicken and beans for her house and business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies and to pay for labor to help with her coffee plantation

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 47 years old and married with seven children.  With two of her children in school, Jocelyn works very hard to provide for them.

Jocelyn's business and family home were destroyed by Super Typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013. Jocelyn has restarted her fish vending business and now needs to provide her family with safe shelter.

Jocelyn has taken a PHP 9,720 housing loan through NWTF in order to purchase materials to rebuild her family home.

She is using the loan to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

Jocelyn is committed to rebuilding her devastated life and in the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more goods to sell such as rice, flour, soft drinks and juices

loans.name: Samaila

texts.en: Samaila remembers not being able to pay school fees during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona member. Now, Samaila, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/hectare this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Samaila is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. Samaila expressed that, “In five years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Samaila is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more coal to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more cooking oil. rice and cooking seasoning to expand her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy hair extensions and hair products.

loans.name: Marie Carmelle

texts.en: Marie Carmelle has been working in the bakery business for more than 10 years. Consequently, she has developed great friendships with employees, and customers, and has found she loves all aspects of the business activity. She is passionate about what she is doing. As result, the bakery occupies an important part of her day.  After several years of hard work, Marie Carmelle and her husband were able to open their own restaurant and bakery store in 2007. Because of the market regularly changing environment for most products, it is always challenging for the business to find out the existing customers’ needs. Today, the customers’ excessive demands have shown the need to acquire more equipment. A Zafen loan will help the business build and maintain successful relationships with potential customers.

loans.use: To purchase a new generator and food products.

loans.name: Bazelais

texts.en: At a young age, Bazelais gained practical sewing experiences by making basic skirts, pants, and simple sewing projects in his mother’s house. His passion led him to spend over 10 years working in a Haitian sewing factory as a production manager. It was during this time he realized that every household has something to be sewn but never finds the time to do it. Moreover, people are in a constant need for clothing adjustments every day because of weight loss or gain.  This personal observation motivated Bazelais to open his own business, to put his personal sewing machine to good use, and start making some extra money. The quality of the products produced by the business has retained clients for years. Today, the business wants to produce more yet is faced with the challenge of not having enough equipment. This issue has caused the business to look for ways to improve its operating performance. A current loan will help the business to buy, 4 regular sewing machines, one cutting sewing machine and raw materials, and provide additional goods and services to its current and potential customers.

loans.use: To purchase four regular sewing machines, one cutting machine and raw materials.

loans.name: G.s San Rafael Group

texts.es:
La señora Mirna es una persona  muy  emprendedora vive con  su esposo y sus   hijos en una comunidad al sur de Honduras. Su negocio es una pulpería desde hace más de 10 años. 
Doña Mirna el préstamo lo necesita para la compra de café,  azúcar, refrescos,  maíz, manteca, carnes, arroz, pan, leche, aguas, etc. Con el préstamo espera  que sus ventas aumenten gracias a que contara con más capital y  productos que ofrecer a los clientes que la visitan.
Doña Mirna al igual que sus compañeras de grupo esperan que esta inversión les ayude a mejorar sus ingresos y así poder seguir apoyando a sus familias en hogar y su sueño es mejorar su casa y ver sus hijos crecer sanos.
Doña Gloria que su negocio es  compra  y venta  de cerdos  y hielo   desde hace 15 años 
Doña Damaris su negocio es la   compra y venta  de cerdos  desde hace 2 años.
Doña Kelyn su negocio es la venta de cerdos desde hace varios años.

Choluteca, Honduras – Junio    del 2014
texts.en:
Mirna is a very enterprising person. She lives with her husband and children in a community in the south of Honduras. Her business for the past 10 years has been a grocery store.

Mirna needs a loan to purchase coffee, sugar, soda, corn, butter, meat, rice, bread, milk, water, etc.. With the loan, she expects sales to increase because she can count on more capital and she will feature more products for customers who visit.

Mirna, like hers associates, hopes that this investment will help her improve her income so she can continue supporting her families at home. Her dream is to improve her home and see her children grow up healthy.

Gloria's business is buying and selling pigs and ice for the past 15 years.  Damaris' business is buying and selling of pigs for the past 2 years.  Kelyn's business is selling pigs for several years.

Choluteca, Honduras - June 2014

loans.use: to buy coffee, sugar, soda, corn, butter, meat, rice, bread, milk, water, etc.. for her business

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en:
Yusuf remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona member. Now, Yusuf, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2,000/hectare this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. 

However, Yusuf is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. “In five years, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty,” expressed Yusuf. With this loan, Yusuf is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double his income and yield.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is widowed with five children, four of whom go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has a business of selling charcoal and has been in this business for 10 years. 

She has applied for a loan of 300,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal. She generates additional income from rental houses and selling piped water. She works from home seven days out of every week and sells on a wholesale basis only. Her major business challenges include transportation and thieves. She is aspiring of owning a delivery van to ease transportation and also to build more rental rooms.  

She resides in the family house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees and paying for utility bills.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Leidy Yohana

texts.es:
La pasión es algo que caracteriza a la joven Leidy que por el color de su pelo representa a la perfección este valor su determinación y empeño que pone en sus ventas y pro sacar adelante su hijo es de admirar pues a sus 24 años de edad es una madre soltera que vela por su criatura de 7 años de edad.
Trabajo como vendedora en una empresa e incluso vendía ropa a sus compañeros de clase, pero hace 2 años comenzó como independiente vendiendo productos por catálogo de uso personal.
Solicita un crédito para comprar productos de la Marca Amway, con la ayuda de este crédito tendrá más surtido para ofertar por lo que sus ventas tendrá un giro positivo generando ingresos que le permitan soñar con tener un local comercial.
texts.en:
Passion is something that characterizes young Leidy.  The color of her hair perfectly represents the merit, determination and effort she puts into her sales.  The sacrifices she makes in order to bring up her child is admired for this 24 year old.  She is a single mother who watches over her child of 7 years of age.

She works as a saleswoman in a clothing company and also sells clothes to her friends.  Two years ago, she began working as an independent catalog salesperson selling products for personal use.

She is requesting a loan to buy Amway brand products.  With the help of this loan, she will have more variety to offer so her sales will have a positive spin, generating revenues that allow her dream of having a shop.

loans.use: to purchase personal care products like soaps, shampoo, toothpaste, etc.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Mark is 27 years old and is the second of three children in the family. His mother, Norma, is a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon and supports her family through her general store business in the Philippines.

Mark is studying automotive mechanics and is currently on his first of this six-month course.

Norma is borrowing 9,885 PHP (Philippines pesos) for the tuition fee of her son Mark for the six months of the school year, 2014-2015.

When he graduates, Mark plans to be gainfully employed to help his family.

loans.use: to pay for her son's tuition fee

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 34 years old, married and has two children, one of whom is in school. 

Jocelyn and her family survived Super Typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013, but her business and family home were wiped out. 

Jocelyn is taking out a housing loan amounting to 9,860 PHP (Philippines pesos) to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor to build a house for her family. 

Jocelyn has been an NWTF borrower since 2012. She plans to recover through her fish-vending business.

With your help, Jocelyn can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of Super Typhoon Haiyan. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more wood for resale.

loans.name: Iliya

texts.en:
Iliya remembers not being able to feed his family during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona member. Now, Iliya, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2,000/hectare this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Iliya is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  

“In five years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community,” expressed Iliya. With this loan, Iliya is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double his income and yield.

Desiree is 52 years old and widowed with five children. She works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 25,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

Desiree has been in this business for four years.

She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fabrics and shoes.

loans.use: To buy fabric for dressmaking.

loans.name: Bature

texts.en: Bature remembers feeling depressed as a result of a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona member. Now, Bature, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Bature is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 50 bags per hectare this season because this loan will give him access to high quality inputs that will positively affect his yield. When asked about his plans for the future, Bature said: “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community."  With this loan, Bature is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: to access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double his income and yield.

loans.name: Lucila

texts.en:
Bryan is 18 years old and is the third of three children in his family. His mother Lucila is a member of Project Dungganon and supports the family through her direct selling of herbal products in the Philippines. Bryan is studying for his bachelors of science in architecture and is currently in the third year of this 5 year course.

Lucila is borrowing 7,677 PHP to pay tuition fees for her son Bryan's 2014-2015/1st semester school year. When he graduates, Bryan plans to finish his studies, have his own house and lot, and help his parents.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees.

loans.name: Lanie

texts.en:
Lanie is 47 years old, married and has two children who are in school.

Lanie and her family survived super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013, but her business and family home were wiped out. 

She is now taking out a housing loan amounting to PHP 9,866 to purchase building materials and to pay for construction labor to build a house for her family. She has been an NWTF borrower since 2011. She plans to repay through her motorcycle transportation business.

With your help, Lanie can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of super typhoon Haiyan. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business and send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and to pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase different kinds of cosmetics to expand her business.

loans.name: Yolly

texts.en:
Yolly is 40 years old, married and has four children, three of whom are currently in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 29,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase materials like gasoline, wood, bamboo, etc. for her business. She has been in this business for 10 years. 

In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase materials like gasoline, wood, bamboo, etc. for her business

This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now Hashimu, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14.

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en: Carolyne is a married woman. She has five children with ages ranging from 10 years to 17 years. She describes herself as patient and honest. She operates a retail business where she sells milk, bread, sugar, flour and other items. She has been involved in this business for four years. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of enough capital. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, bread, milk and other items. Her business goal is to earn more profit within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: buy more stock of sugar, bread, milk and other items

loans.name: Rocelyn

texts.en:
Rocelyn is 47 years old and married with two children who are in school.

She earns a living by farming garden plants in the Philippines. Rocelyn is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.

Rocelyn has been farming garden plants for 23 years and also earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Yohanna

texts.en: Yohanna remembers feeling depressed during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona member. Now Yohanna, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/hectare this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yohanna  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. “In five years, I want to make more money for myself and my family,” explained Yohanna. With this loan, Yohanna is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: to access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en: Jonathan is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. He joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children. Jonathan is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, he will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Jonathan can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and earn up to $2000/hectare, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money to expand my farmland.” Jonathan is not thinking about this year alone. He expressed that his long-term goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: to access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Amigas Por Siempre Iii Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “AMIGAS POR SIEMPRE III” iniciará el primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Los Andes, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Justina es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: tejido de chompas, venta de comida, venta de stiker, costura de pantalones, venta de manteles, costura de ropa, tienda de barrio, costura de busos.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Justina es integrante, ella indica que hace un año que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una amiga que es cliente de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de tejido de mantas de vicuña; da a conocer que este negocio lo aprendió de su madre, a quien desde niña apoyaba en este mismo negocio, al casarse decide emprender de forma independiente su negocio. 
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de fibra de vicuña y alpaca por mayor) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas de la ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializará a pedido de la clienta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia, ya que ella es casada y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el área de salud y la capacitación que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The communal bank "AMIGAS POR SIEMPRE III" is beginning its first Pro Mujer loan cycle at the Los Andes social Center.  It comprises eight members and is led by a board of directors whose president is Justina.  The members are involved in different business activities that include: knitting, sales, sewing, and a grocery store.

The loan will benefit small business owners including Justina.  She has been a member of Pro Mujer for a year and joined by invitation from a friend who is a customer of the institution.  Justina currently knits blankets using vicuña wool which she learned about from her mother.  When she was a little girl she would help out in the same business.  When she married she decided to go into business independently.

The loan she is requesting now is to buy vicuña and alpaca wool from wholesale vendors in the city of El Alto.  Later she will make her goods and sell them based on customer orders.  This work allows her to generate income to support her family.  She is married and has three children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she says it is the health area and training offered by the institution.

loans.use: To buy vicuña and alpaca wool wholesale.

loans.name: Jose Alvaro

texts.es:
José un orgullo agricultor, el cual ha vivido y crecido junto al campo y los animales, convirtiendo al campo y a los animales en su actividad económica con la que diariamente genera los recursos para llevar la alimentación a su hogar y los familiares que depende de él.
Se dedica a la cría de ganado y paralelo con esto tiene cultivos de yuca y plátano. 
Solicita un crédito para la compra de más ganado para obtener mejores ganancias pues la agricultura ha tenido una desvaloración importante y no es tan rentable, pero el seguirá fiel al estilo de vida con el que ha podido conformar un hogar sólido. 
El crédito le ayuda a obtener mejores ganancias para pensar en expandir sus predios y cultivar otras verduras
texts.en:
Jose is a proud farmer who has grown up and lived in the country with animals.  They have become his business activity to generate a daily income to put food on the table for the family which is dependent on him.

He raises cattle and also grows yucca and banana.  The loan he is requesting is to buy cattle to increase his profit since agriculture has suffered a significant devaluation and is no longer as profitable.  He wants to remain loyal to his lifestyle which has given him a stable home life.

The loan will help him improve his profit so he can expand his business and grow other vegetables.

loans.use: To buy cattle.

loans.name: Saratu

texts.en: Saratu remembers not being able to feed her family during a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Saratu, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2,000/hectare this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Saratu is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs,” expressed Saratu. With this loan, Saratu is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double her income and yield.

loans.name: Unión Progreso Y Futuro Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “UNIÓN PROGRESO Y FUTURO” iniciará el trigésimo segundo ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Santiago II, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Maribel es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: costura de edredones, tienda de barrio, tejido de ropa de niños, elaboración de mantas de alpaca y vicuña, venta de ropa de bebe, taller de confección, tienda de barrio, venta de zapatillas deportivas.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Maribel es integrante, ella indica que hace tres años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de un prima que es clienta de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de  venta de ropa; da a conocer que la venta de este producto lo aprendió de su madre y cuando decide establecer una familia emprenden este negocio con el apoyo de un pequeño ahorro. 
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de ropa por mayor) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas y posteriormente lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyarse económicamente en sus estudios.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el área de salud que ofrece la institución.

En la imagen no esta presente una de las socias, por razones de su negocio se tuvo que ir con urgencia.
texts.en:
The communal bank "UNION PROGRESO Y FUTURO" is beginning its 32nd Pro Mujer loan cycle at the Santiago II social center.  The group comprises eight members whose board of directors is led by the president, Maribel.  The members are involved in different business activities including, sewing, knitting, alpaca wool blanket making, a grocery store, baby clothes sales, and sport shoes sales.

The loan being requested will benefit small business owners including Maribel who joined Pro Mujer three years ago.  She joined by invitation through a cousin who is a customer of the institution.  Maribel currently sells clothing and learned about the business from her mother.  When she decided to establish her own family she set up her own busines with a small amount of savings.
 
The loan she is requesting is to buy clothing from wholesale dealers to sell in her retail space.  Her work allows her to generate an income to support herself economically with regard to her education. 

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she says it is the health area offered by the institution.

One of the members is not present in the photo because of a business related emergency.

loans.use: To buy wholesale clothing.

loans.name: 18 De Septiembre Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “18 DE SEPTIEMBRE” iniciará el décimo primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Santiago II, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Rosario es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de deportivos femeninos, venta de condimentos, venta de comida, tienda de barrio, venta de cosméticos, venta de golosinas, venta de salchipapas, servicio de transporte.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Rosario es integrante, ella indica que hace cinco años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de su madre que es clienta de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de  venta de cosméticos; da a conocer que este negocio lo implementó hace varios años atrás, al observar la demanda de los productos en el mercado. 
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de cosméticos por mayor) que adquirirá de las distribuidoras mayoristas y posteriormente lo comercializará a pedido de la cliente. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyarse económicamente en sus estudios.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el área de capacitación que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The communal bank "18 DE SEPTIEMBRE" is beginning its firts Pro Mujer loan cycle at the Santiago II social center.  The group comprises eight members whose board of directors is led by the president, Rosario.  The members are involved in different business activities which include sales of women's sport clothes, seasonings, food, cosmetics, sweets, hot dogs, a grocery store and a transport business.

The loan will benefit small business owners, including Rosario who joined Pro Mujer five years ago.  She joined by invitation through her mother who is a member of the institution.  Rosario currently sells cosmetics and started her activity several years ago because she observed a market demand for these products.
 
The loan she is requesting is to buy wholesale cosmetics which she will sell to customers based on orders.  This way of working allows her to generate resources to support herself economically with regard to her education.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she says it is the training offered by the institution.

loans.use: To buy wholesale cosmetics.

loans.name: Mafinga Group

texts.en:
Zoona is a mother of two schooling kids. She is in her 30s. She is married and has been involved with a shop selling clothes and CDs. This is a business she has been engaged in since 2009. She is a hardworking woman. Working from 8 am to 9 pm daily, she is able to realize a very good profit. 

This is her first loan request, which she will share with her group "Mafinga", which includes six members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan. She wants a loan to invest in her shop with more fashionable clothes for the coming Muslim ceremony and more CDs.
  
Zoona desires to greatly improve her business and become an international businesswoman.

loans.use: to replenish her shop with clothes and CDs to resell.
